quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 5 Quiz 3
quiz.subtitle: 5.3: Relating Intermolecular Forces to Physical Properties
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: Generally, how does the strength of intermolecular forces affect the boiling point of a liquid?
options: Stronger IMFs lead to a higher boiling point
Stronger IMFs lead to a lower boiling point
IMFs only affect melting point, not boiling point
There is no predictable relationship between IMFs and boiling point
questions.explanation: Boiling requires overcoming the attractions between molecules. Stronger IMFs require more thermal energy (higher temperature) to pull molecules apart into the gas phase.

questions.question: Which of the following substances would you expect to have the highest boiling point?
questions.explanation: Methanol can form hydrogen bonds (O-H), which are significantly stronger than the dipole-dipole forces in $CH_3Cl$ or the dispersion forces in the non-polar alkanes.

questions.question: The phrase 'like dissolves like' refers to which property related to IMFs?
questions.explanation: Substances with similar IMFs (e.g., two polar substances or two non-polar substances) tend to be soluble in each other because they can form similar attractive interactions.

questions.question: Why does $n$-pentane (a straight chain) have a higher boiling point than neopentane (a branched/spherical molecule), even though they have the same formula ($C_5H_{12}$)?
options: The straight chain has a larger surface area, leading to stronger London dispersion forces
The straight chain is more polar
The branched molecule has hydrogen bonding
The straight chain has stronger covalent bonds
questions.explanation: Molecules with larger surface areas have more points of contact for London dispersion forces to act, increasing the total attraction compared to compact, spherical isomers.

questions.question: If a substance has a very low melting point and does not conduct electricity as a liquid, it is most likely held together by:
questions.explanation: Molecular solids are held by relatively weak IMFs, resulting in low melting points. They lack mobile ions or electrons, so they do not conduct electricity.

questions.question: Which of these gases would deviate the MOST from 'ideal' behavior at low temperatures?
questions.explanation: Ideal gases are assumed to have no attractions. $NH_3$ has strong hydrogen bonding, which creates significant attractions between particles, causing it to deviate more than non-polar gases.

questions.question: Which substance would be the MOST soluble in water ($H_2O$)?
questions.explanation: Water is polar and forms hydrogen bonds. Ammonia is also polar and can hydrogen-bond with water, making it highly soluble. The other options are non-polar.

questions.question: As the molar mass of a series of non-polar noble gases increases (He to Xe), the boiling point:
options: Stays the same because they are all non-polar
Decreases because larger atoms move slower
questions.explanation: Larger atoms have more electrons and a more easily distorted electron cloud (higher polarizability), leading to stronger London dispersion forces.

questions.question: A substance that is a liquid at room temperature likely has:
questions.explanation: If IMFs were extremely weak, it would be a gas. If they were extremely strong (like ionic or network covalent bonds), it would likely be a solid.

questions.question: Which of the following would have the lowest vapor pressure at a given temperature?
options: A substance with strong hydrogen bonds
A substance with only weak dispersion forces
A substance with a low molar mass
questions.explanation: Vapor pressure is the pressure of gas above a liquid. Strong IMFs hold molecules in the liquid phase more tightly, so fewer escape into the gas phase, resulting in lower vapor pressure.

scoreMessages.90: Masterful! You can predict a substance's behavior just by looking at its structure.
scoreMessages.70: Great work. You have a solid grasp of how 'sticky' molecules are.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: stronger attraction = higher boiling point.
scoreMessages.0: Review the link between polarity, hydrogen bonding, and energy requirements for phase changes.
